derivation.yuyuan_name: Old English flēan, of Germanic origin; related to Middle Dutch vlaen

entry.def: When someone flays an animal or person, they remove their skin, usually when they are dead.

example.ex: They had to flay the great, white, fleecy animals and cut them up for food...
example.tran: 他们不得不将这些体形庞大、身披绒毛的白色动物剥皮，然后切碎了做食物。

example.ex: To remain together was like volunteering to be flayed alive.
example.tran: 再要呆在一起就好像自愿被活活剥皮一样。

entry.def: If you flay someone, you criticize them severely for their beliefs, policies, or actions.

example.ex: ...and he flayed those who allowed 'foreign potentates and powers' to violate American sovereignty.
example.tran: 他还鞭挞那些允许“外国君主和势力”侵犯美国主权的人。

auth_sentence.content: "They were like incredible throwdowns, " says Bobby Flay, the celebrity chef who also buys and breeds racehorses.

sentences.en: He was so angry he nearly flayed his horse alive.
sentences.cn: 他气得几乎把马活活抽死。

sentences.en: You cannot flay the same ox twice.
There he was condemned to death by the king, and before being beheaded he was flayed alive.
sentences.cn: 他被那里的国王定为死罪，在被砍头之前，活活地剥了皮。

sentences.en: The teacher flayed the idle students.
sentences.cn: 老师严责那些懒惰的学生。
